docs.text: the police negotiator is the person with the entirely unenviable job of going into ground zero and attempting to talk a dangerous criminal out of doing whatever he or she intends to do .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: lives are often at stake , and the criminal is usually armed and most likely mentally unstable , prone to turn on the negotiator at a moment's notice .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the negotiator must therefore be something of an actor , psychologist , and sham artist , in addition to being a police officer ; he must be able to think on his feet and either work toward the goal of ending the confrontation without violence , or failing that , must be prepared to facilitate the conclusion of the crisis through firepower .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: most of all , the negotiator must be able to enter a situation with as little intelligence about the scenario as possible , and quickly gain control of the situation , dominate the conversation , and influence the perpetrator into thinking that the end of the conflict is what he really wants .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it takes a pretty smart person to do that .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but what if the hostage-holding criminal is just as smart ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: what if he's also able to think on his feet ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in fact , what if he also knows all the tricks to turning the situation to his favor ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it is this circumstance which forms the basis for f . gary gray's the negotiator .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in this film , police negotiator danny roman ( samuel l . jackson ) is tipped off by his partner to corruption within the chicago police force .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when his partner turns up shot to death and internal affairs finds incriminating evidence in roman's home , roman becomes the prime suspect of both embezzling from the police disability fund and murder .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: faced with the scorn of most of the police department , and under close scrutiny by the media , roman is forced to turn in his badge in one of those typical scenes in the captain's office .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i don't quite remember if the captain actually said , " i hate to do this , but . . . " ,
docs.label: positive

docs.text: although it wouldn't surprise me if he did .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: luckily , the film soon shakes off the conventionalism and concentrates on the interesting premise mentioned above .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: after being offered a take-it-or-leave-it deal by the district attorney , roman resolves to prove his innocence by walking into the office of internal affairs inspector niebaum ( j . t .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: walsh ) , taking him and others hostage , and proclaiming he has been framed .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: although roman's actions seem forced due to the compressed nature of his motivational build-up , gray redeems himself by involving us with the negotiations between roman and fellow police negotiator chris sabian ( kevin spacey ) which soon ensue .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: jackson , while a superb actor , is miscast in the role of roman .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the actor has become so popular , and so often identified as a protagonist ( notable exceptions can be found , such as in jackie brown ) , that we as an audience have a difficult time believing he will carry out his threats .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the script also clearly sets him up as the good guy who is only trying to prove his innocence .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: how can we believe he's going to shoot a hostage , no matter if the hostage tried to kill him earlier ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: unfortunately , this preconception saps the film of some of it's would-be suspenseful moments , and anything good left in those scenes is largely attributed to jackson's acting ability .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: almost every time he's in a scene , jackson steals it without looking back .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when spacey appears , the film has already run about a third of its course .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his is an interesting character .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: made out to be some kind of negotiating superman , our first look at him has him hopelessly trying to get his family moving to set out on vacation .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: " i can talk a man out of blowing up the sears tower , but i can't talk my wife out of the bedroom or my daughter off the phone , " he says .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when he gets the call to action , however , he quickly changes gears and becomes the man we expect him to be .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: soon , his character has to negotiate not only with roman , but also with the swat commander ( david morse ) who is itching to send in a team to take roman out , all the while keeping wary of the fbi agents who are waiting to take over the operation , should negotiations fail .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this complex set of pressures are reflected well in sabian the negotiator and spacey the actor .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: as the second protagonist , spacey measures up nicely .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: gray really lucked out with this cast .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: david morse as commander beck , ron rifkin as commander frost , and john spencer as police chief al travis are all more than competent , and can hold their own in scenes with jackson and spacey .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the only problem is the bit of typecasting that results from these choices : morse played a similar role in the rock , rifkin played the d . a .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in l . a . confidential , and spencer played a police detective in cop land .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: with the level of acting , however , this can be forgiven .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: also in the supporting cast , paul giamatti as rudy , one of the hostages , is notable for the comic relief he provides .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his character is initially so slimy , and giamatti himself just looks so shifty , that you expect to laugh before he even says anything .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: fortunately , this doesn't distract from the seriousness of the rest of the film , but instead provides some nice breathers from the level of tension which gray manages to sustain throughout .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: j . t . walsh , as the suspicious internal affairs inspector , clocks in with one of his final performances .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: sadly , the talented but underrated actor passed away in late february of this year , and the soon to be released pleasantville will mark his last film .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: walsh appeared in dozens of movies such as good morning vietnam , backdraft , and nixon .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: for one of his best performances , check out sling blade , in which he plays a mental patient sharing a ward with billy bob thornton .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when jack nicholson accepted his best actor oscar in march , walsh was one of the men to whom he credited his success ( the actors performed together in a few good men ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the negotiator is actually dedicated to walsh , and while inspector niebaum may not have been his best role , it certainly characterizes the type of character for which walsh had become most famous for playing .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: in the end , the negotiator has a plotline that parallels it's reality .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: we're served with the premise that two equally deft negotiators are battling each other to resolve the conflict in the manner which will suit each of them best .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: as an audience , we're also given a situation where two wonderfully talented actors are thrown into a movie , and we'd like to see if one will dominate the film .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: both provide some pretty good entertainment .
docs.label: positive
